On Tue, 30 Sep 2003, Ilja Preuss wrote:

> > Interpretation cannot be avoided if you use interfaces, abstraction,
> > and operations like instanceof.
>
> I'd think that C++ does provide the same features, doesn't it? Would you
> say it's an interpreted language?

Yes, to a degree.  However, C++ deals with much of this at compile time.
Think template metaprogramming.  Typical benchmarks show C++ running at
97% or so of the speed of C.  As you add interpretation, the speed goes
down.

This is an old issue.  About 20 years ago, Intel had two candidate
future CPUs.  One was the 386, and the other was the iAPX 432, a machine
designed to run object-oriented languages, Smalltalk in particular.
This was an exciting project.  Books and papers were written on the
subject; people knew that this was the way of the future.

But after a bright beginning, the 432 project was destroyed by benchmarks
published by a team at the University of California at Berkeley.  These
showed the 432 being easily beaten by, as I recall, an Intel 8080 (8086?),
a commodity 8-bit processor.

The benchmarks were biased; they had been set up by the RISC team at
Berkeley, who had a vested interest in seeing complex architectures fail.
However, the point proven was that object-oriented programming techniques
and run-time interpretation have a high overhead.

Please bear in mind when considering these remarks that I was one of those
excited by the 432 ;-)
